div1.opener: United States Consulate at St Paul de Loanda to the Department of State
div1.p: Mr. Robert Scott Newton
Subject: Cotton Goods
Abstract of Contents: General information concerning Cotton Goods with full particulars as to Prices qualities etc and samples sent per Book Post
div1.note: (Copied for the Review of Statistics, Dec. 1880) Commpared with proof. Oct. 3/81
div1.p: United States Consulate St Paul de Loanda 14 September 1880
Sir With reference to circular of March 19th marked separate. I have the honor to say that the yams principally referred to are not imported into this market.

The goods principally used in this trade are as follows, and I beg to submit the following information in reference to same as it may be useful to merchants & manufacturers actions to cultivate this trade.
Sample No 1

Grey Domestics Portuguese name Algodoes of good quality 30 yards long by 25 inches wide put info in Bales of 100 fees each piece everything from 7 1/2 tts to 9 tts. To be doubled in 40 folds or laps. They generally have a good deal of March which makes them sell better.

Best price in England. Selling price in Loanda 6/ to 6/10 per piece Rs 2400 or 2 dolls 60 cents pieces of 30 yds by 22 inches:- of per piece Rs 1900 or 2$ 06 cents fee 30 yards b7 30 inches weight per piece 8 3/4 to 9 1/2 tts only small quantity used
used
Cost price in England Selling price in Loanda 1/2 to 8/6 Rs 3000 or 3$ 26c per piece
Sample No 2 Striped Denims or Blue & White Stripes Portuguese name Riscaos Americanos Estrecto
pieces 18 yards long by 25 inches wide-- noted colours 60 pieces per Bale Weighing per piece 4 to 4 1/2 tts
Cost price in England Selling price in Loanda 5/2 to 5/6 per piece Rs 2040 or 2$ 22cts per piece Striped Denims Portuguese term Riscados Americanos largos
pieces 18 yards long by 30 inches no Red colors 60 pieces per Bale. Weighting per pieces 4 1/2 to 5tts
Cost England Selling price in Loanda 6/10 to 7/2 per price Rs 2640 or 2$ 87c per price
Sample No 3 Blue & White checks Portuguese name Riscados Clemnbos or Maclussos
Length & width, selling prices, weight etc. same as Striped Denims both wide & narrow quality used These generally come out a or so dearer than the stripes

Sample No 4 Blue Raft Portuguese name Zuarte pieces
pieces 28 yards in length by 40 inches wide. Weight per piece 7 to 8 1/2 tts 100 pieces per Bale
Cost price in england Selling price Loanda 9/3 to 10/ per piece Rs 4200 or 4$ 56c per piece
Sample No 5 Fancy prints Portugese name Clutas with clear ground and fast colors- 25 to 26 yards long, by 30 inches wide - 60 pieces pere case Weight per piece 5tts
Cost price in England Selling price in Loanda 8/6 to 9/ per piece Rs 3600 or 3$ 91c per piece
Sample No 6 Brilliantes Portugueses name Illusselinas Pieces 26 yards long & 30 inches wide- 100 pieces per case Weight 4 3/4 tts per piece
Cost price in England Selling price in Loanda 8/6 to 9/ per piece Rs 3600 or 3$ 91c per piece
Sample No 7 While Shirtings Portugueses name Morium or kammo kalente prices 24 yards long, by 35 to 36 inches wide Weight about 5 1/4 tts per piece

Cost price in England Selling price Loanda 8/ to 8/9 per piece Rs 3800 or 4$ 13c per piece All the above goods are sold in Loanda retail
retail by the piece to the better class of natives.
A considerable quantity is also used up country in the Barter trade for coffee and Rubber although the following are the staple goods used in the Barter Trade.

In 1877 several prices of goods of very good quality were brought in American Vessels as samples but they were unsailiable on account of the sizes being different. The Cloth was good and if it had been put up in proper sizes would have sold well.
Sample No 8 Common Striped Denims Portuguese name Riscados Americanos ordinarios pieces of 16 to 17 yards long & 23 to 24 inches wide- doubled in 18 folds or laps. 100 pieces per Bale
Cost price in England Selling price in Loanda 2/28 2/6 to 3/ per price Rs 850 to 1000 or 92ct to $1.02c
Sample No 9 Common Blue & White Checks. Portuguese name Rescados churnlos ordinarios Price, length width etc same as above

Sample No 10 Common Blue Baft. Portuguese name zuarte ordinario 16
16 yards long by 26 inches wide- 100 pieces per bale to be doubled in 18 folds or laps.
Cost price in England Selling price in Loanda 2/2 per piece Rs 900 to 1000 or 97c to $1.08c
Sample No 11 Satin Stripes Portuguese name Pilados pieces of lb to 17 yards long by 25 inches wide 100 pieces per Bale -- to be doubled in 18 folds ot laps
Cost price in England Selling price in Loanda Blue White 3/ per piece Rs 1100 or $1.12cts per piece Yellow 3/5 ,, ,, Rs 1000 or $1.41cts ,, ,,
Sample No 12 Chilloes Portueguese name Fazecida de Lei 15 to 17 yards long by 27 inches wide- 120 pieces per Bale. To be doubled in 17 folds or laps.
Cost in England Selling price in Loanda 2/3, 2/6 to 3/ per piece Rs 1000 to 1050 or $1.08cts to $1.14cts

Sample No 13 Striped Florentenes. Portuguese name Riscados azues ordinarios pieces of 16 to 17 yards long by 23 inches wide-- 100 pieces per Bale -- to be doubled in 18 folds or laps: cost
Cost price in England Selling price in Loanda 2/9 to 3/10 per piece Rs 1200 to 1500 or $1.30cts

All these should be well starched or sized much more so than the finer goos as they are all for the Barler Trade. There is great competition in this trade, so often they come a yard orso shorter, and an inch or so narrow, but all doubled to imitate goods of 18 yards which used to be the regulation length
Great attention sohould be paid to the regularity of the pieces in each Bale and to the packing.

Many qualities of Handkerchiefs also are in use, ranging from 12 to 15 Handkerchiefs per price. However I do not send sample of these as the quality is so varied, and nearly all styles and qualities pass.

The duty on the above mentioned Cotton Goods is as follows: 85 Rs = 90 cts per Kello are Sample No 1 230 Rs = 25 ,, ,, ,, ,, ,, No 2/13 and 4% wore on the value here, which is usually calculated at about 30% over the Invoice
Invoice price.

When these goods come in a Lisbon or from Lisbon in a Portuguese vessel they pay 70% of the before mentioned duties. Manufactured in Portugal and bringing a Certifcate to that effect they pay only 20% of the beforementioned duty.
Should they come in Foreign Vessels from any other Country they pay the full amount of duty as previously stated.
Shortly as new Tariff is to be brought into force which will increase the duty on better goods considerably.
As soon as I can obtain a copy I will send it to the Department with a translation.

Nearly all cotton goods came from Liverpool and London in steamer to Lisbon and thence in the portuguese steamers. All Lisbon they pay a small duty which allows them to pass here paying only 70% of the duty.
The expenses via Lisbon from England including carriage from Manchester to Liverpool Sury & Cartage freight marriage by steamers to Lisbon & afterwards to this port.

Duty in Lisbon without commission is about 14% to 15% all
All these goods are used in the Province of Angola, but at Ambriz and the North the sizes vary, and the trade is different.
My information is taken from different Invoices received by mercantile Houses established here.
The portuguese steamers leave Lisbon on the 5th of every month for this port touching at the other Portuguese colonies.
There are also two lines of steamers from Liverpool, but it does not suit to ship Cotton goods by these on account of the extra 30% duty the Cosigners would have to pay.
Nearly all goods that come here are in execution of orders on acount and risk of the merchants here.
Consignmemts are not large although a well assorte establishment might do a good trade, as often the traders run short of different qualities in their assortments.

The usual Commissions are 5% for selling and 2% for remitting in Bils and 4% for remitting in produce. Some Houses however do thew whole busiess for 5% comission without guarantee & 8% with
with guarantee.
It is difficult to give the number of pieces used during a year as no statistical statement of same is kept in the Custom House.
However I know of Houses here that use from 40 to 50,000 pieces in a year.
The trade is nearly all in the hands of the Portuguese-, and it would be difficult to get orders from this market.
Lately travellers have been here from England and Germany to solicit orders but have done little or nothing.
The Exchange is Rs 4500 per f1 sterling, or 920 Reis per Dollar-
I have the honor to be, Your most obedient servant, Robert S Newton US Vice Consul
To the Assistant Secretary of State Washington, D.C.
